This game said it was free to play… they lied. It costs friendships. You think you’re just dropping in with your boys? Nah. You’re dropping into emotional bankruptcy. One second you’re all laughing, the next second Chad ‘accidentally’ forgets to cover your flank and your million-dollar kit is gone. Now you’re broke AND you hate Chad.

This isn’t a shooter, it’s a social experiment. Arena Breakout Infinite doesn’t just test your aim, it tests your ability to forgive betrayal, cope with poverty, and resist the urge to uninstall Discord. GG devs, you made the first truly pay-to-friendship game.

The game is great, but it has many flaws, which other players have pointed out in angry comments. I've been playing for 23 hours and haven't encountered any cheaters, only those who scan crates for valuable loot, but otherwise, I haven't encountered any. Playing solo is pointless; it quickly becomes boring and leaves only a bad impression. But if you grab a couple of friends or meet some people in matchmaking and play in a group, it won't even matter whether you lose the raid or not; it'll be fun (that's what we came for). Dying alone with 700,000 loot, or playing in a group, replaying positions, exchanging fire with other players, and dying—it's not that annoying.

Honestly, the game is for an amateur, for those tired of Tarkov and want to try something different. Because most of the people I've met here are grown men from the factory who either play CS:GO like gods, or young guys who buy sniper rifles and sit in the bushes for 30 minutes waiting for someone to show up.

The developers are working hard and constantly delight us with new bonuses, like gear and updates. The game is still being refined, and the developers are listening to player feedback.

A PVP focused Extraction Shooter where the PVP aspect is by far the weakest part. 

First the positives: 
-easy to pick up
-easy gun customization 
-easy Call of Duty-esque get back into action quick playstyle
-nice graphics
-nice sound design: overall sound design not talking about footsteps in particular
-good variety of maps and loot

the in-between:
-player driven economy
-relatively decent exploration even outside of the main POIs
-ability to play what you like 
-"tiered" progression
-satisfying loot experience (more prior to recent update now not so much anymore further detail in the lower section)

the bad:
-directional audio: it's buggy sometimes, esp when it comes to elevation changes
-gunfights: this gets picked up in the next section further down so look there for an explanation
-current looting experience: since the latest update you now immediately know if an item is high in value or not bc high value items now take longer to be identified compared to regular items

the ugly:
-cheating: yes they ban cheaters, yes they have an anti-cheat, does it stop ppl from cheating? well ofc iit does not, every MP game will have that problem and i am fully aware of that, the problem here is that your loadout is on the line so if you have a high value loadout you're much more likely to store it then to use it or you play iin secure-ops where you can't lose your loot
-economy: some players have millions upon millions if not billions extracted, you get to keep you money past "wipes" so those players have an immediate advantage over new players and can diictate market prices, yes the game does combat that somewhat by giving out tier 4 gear like candy but that doesn't help against artificial inflation of ammo and gear prices esp above tier 4
-gunfights: Part 1 PVE: like i said above, the point returns, why? Bc it fits both categories, gunfights against bots are by enlarge mundane and more nuisance than challenge, i get it just like in Arc Raiders the bots are supposed to be a nuisance that you have to take into calculation for gunfights and can use as an asset, the only exception to this are bosses and the additional spawns alongside them as they usually carry higher tier gear, react faster etc. i'm not saying bots should be as overpowered as they are/were in Gray Zone Warfare but i wish there would be different tiers of AI and esp the AI in TV-Station, inside Armory and inside the Hotel on Northridge could def pose more of a threat than they do now. Part 2 PVP: gunfights in PVP are insanely hit or miss, either you get matched with people with full Tier 6 armor, H416 or Mosin with Tier 7 ammo, usually in a duo, trio or squad stack or you get matched against people doing corpse runs i.e. standard kit, no helmet <200k loot value, no in between, the former you will not win against nor will they lose any money while "risking" their gear bc their friends will just pick up what they had on and exfil right away, the latter you prob spend more money than you gain, this is by no means exclusive to ABI but it somehow feels unfair nonetheless
-matchmaking: if you're a new player who just started out and you get matched against seasonalnolife557 with 20bn extracted tell me where the balancing is, one risks his loadout with the potential of going broke while the other sits on stacks of cash throwing one Mosin with full red ammo and 50 slot backpack filled with nades and stims into the raid one after another without a care in the world part of the experience? absolutely, the norm? it shouldn't be.
-PVP: by far the worst part of the game, the game has to my knowledge 24-tickrate servers, that is quite abysmal, heavy desyncs are a feature, trust me, i do not know why they even feature a killcam when 90% of the kills look like they're cheated but are simply a problem of desync, overall the PVP aspect is heavily unbalanced and in many cases actually unfun, why can people bring full tier 5 gear and an M4 with a semi decent kit 60 round mags full of tier 4 ammo into a raid with a value cap of 450k, well simple, they cheat the system, bc mags can be stored in backpacks and do not contribute to equipment value that way, worn armor is valued less than new armor, which makes sense but then you should add a gear cap instead restrict the items ppl can bring into a raid by making it so the lowest mode (450k equip value) can only be tier 3 or lower and do not allow crafted items, then for the next difficulty make it tier 4 + 5 only (unable to queue with tier 6 stuff but able to queue with <tier 4) and then lastly a open difficulty where absolutely everything goes but a minimal amount of loot value has to be equipped (basically like it is now)
-high value loot (red items): prob the most dividing point of criticism i have but i think high value loot (red items) should not be allowed in safe storage, yes they are rare and insanely valuable but exactly due to that reason it should be high risk, high reward, not, get lucky, store in safe container and don't care anymore, PVP is the center of the game, therefore it would only make sense if red items could not be stored in a safe box and instead drives up the risk and adds more tension in an otherwise, "oh red, nice *put in safe*, *runs to exfil*, *dies*, eeeh whatever at least i got 1.6 mill loot value :)" scenario.

After a couple of hours into the game, I feel like I can pitch in and say a thing or two about it.
Tl;dr, Tarkov and COD had a baby, this is it. Arcadey with a smidge of difficulty, some quests and maps that are either very "boring" in terms of design or labyrinths until you get the gist of them. I'd highly recommend giving it a shot for at least about 10-15 hours.

Now, if you're bored and wanna read more bullsh-t, let's talk about it in detail.

Difficulty levels:

1; Normal. This is aimed at new players looking to get acquainted with the game, controls, how the guns feel and what there is to do in this game. You have access to two maps, Farm and Valley, and regardless of which one you pick, you will be matched against what feels like 2 real players and a couple of AI "players".

2; Lockdown. This is the sweet spot for me, more loot, better gear, higher risk & reward, seen only 4-5 cheaters here, even those are a big ol' MAYBE as I want to give them benefit of "Maybe he had a better headset or something idk". Costs money to enter, you need gear to be above 100k value to enter, you can run budget builds or go full out and run a good T5 kit.

3; Forbidden. Can't say I like this one, if you're a casual gamer, I'd suggest sticking to lockdown, this is intended for people who are REALLY good at the game and know the maps in&out, and get prepared to be nuked. Want to play solo? Enjoy the artillery strike by a four man squad tossing dozens of nades towards you. There also seems to be a large amount of cheaters in this gamemode, per other people I've spoken to, I've played 5 games of forbidden in total, died to an extract camper once, cheaters twice (zooming through the map, bhopping) and the other two games were fair play, I didn't know the maps well enough at the time, but I'd go as far as to call them sweaty because who knows pixel perfect lineups.....?

4; Solo. This is beautiful and I think that more games need this, not just extraction shooters. Your friends are taking a break, or at work? Hop in a solo match, no need to worry about being out numbered by friends with perfect communication over discord, sure, enemies may collude against you, but that's raaaaaare.

//Weapons and gunplay
Weapons? Oh, we've got plenty of guns to choose from, no matter the gun, it feels good to shoot, but you literally can't run anything below T3 ammo or else it's going to hit you with a "Did not penetrate" when you inevitably die. Guns aren't that costly, there're certain attachments that cost an arm and a leg, and two days ago we saw an insane price mark up in scopes, but I'm glad they're going down again. Good scopes cost a LOT of money, I kinda understand why but at the same time, what the f-.

//Gear.
Helmets come in two variations, those that allow you to wear headphones and those that don't. The ones that allow you to wear headphones, choice is yours, you can either wear a pair or hope to get one from an enemy (some people don't run any, ever. Psychos.). Helmets that don't allow you to wear headphones are further split into two different categories, those that block sound and kick your master volume down, and those that come with built in headphones. I personally LOVE the helicopter helmet when running on a budget as it offers full face protection, comes with decent headphones AND it has good durability.
Body wear is split into two categories, armor and armored rigs, difference is that with armor, you can wear a rig separately, whereas with an armored rig the rig is built in. Armored rigs are budget friendly and rather handy in certain situations, but I'd suggest against them overall, two reasons. You get into combat, your armor gets torn, you can't quick swap with enemy armor cuz then you have to transfer your mags to their rig, and it's very limiting. Why not just run armor and grab a rig from an enemy? Or, why not run a rig only and grab armor from an enemy?
Backpacks are, eh, I don't wanna delve into them, weight plays a huge factor in movement and stamina in this game so a lot of players don't really run backpacks as they hope to grab one from an enemy they kill or from AI. They're split into multiple categories too but the most common backpack(s) I see are the RushTac and the 926, though in my humble opinion I think the Chapman is the best backpack in the game, it's cheap, large enough to fit in plenty of loot and it weighs less than the AMP7 which offers 2 slots extra, which just isn't worth it imo.

//Repetitiveness and replayability.
This is a tough one. I guess it depends on the person playing, but here's the main question. Do you like battle royales? If yes, then this is probably a decent contender. But hold on, this is not a BR, this is an extraction shooter, what do you mean? It's arcadey enough to not bore you or require too much grinding to get decent gear and it's got maps that are neither too big nor too small, instead of "dropping" somewhere the game gives you a sh*t spawn and then you make your way to where action's gonna be and duke it out.

//Final say.
I've no idea what else to say, game's fun, it's *kinda* pay to "win" but not nearly as much as other games, let me explain. You can pay for a bigger safe (you also get free trials, I think you can rack it up to 30~ish days if you start now), you can buy 2x2 or 2x3 ($5 and $15 respectively), you also get other benefits such as increased weekly limits for market listing, increased market listings at the same time, extra storage with the $15, but here's the kicker. IF you buy the battle pass (which is worth every penny if you ask me) you get the $15 "elite privilege" as well for 30 days..... which is basically battle pass+elite priv, two for the price of one. Other than this, I can't really say there's anything else that's pay to win. If, like me, you prefer not to queue with random squads or simply want to avoid dealing with toxic teammates or other people’s mistakes, you’ll often find yourself outnumbered in any given match. That means your survival rate depends entirely on your own decisions and awareness.

You can “rat” your way through matches and survive, but that playstyle quickly becomes dull. Let me start off by saying, that this is a hardcore game. You may think, i'm in the middle of nowhere, there's no loot or anything, there shouldn't be anyone here, so i will jus... i'm dead. You need to be laser focused, no background TV or music, no hands free phone calls during the game, you have to see and hear everything! Obviously, it's an extraction shooter, so you have to invest a lot of Koen (in-game currency) in gear and ammo, to increase your chances of winning a gunfight. But the more you invest, the sweatier your hands will be and the more you'll be mad that a sniper tapped you, out of nowhere.

Keep in mind, this is just my experience, not the ultimate facts, you may give the game a try and relate with none of this.

Negatives:
-Matchmaking. The beginner game mode (Normal's) is not beginner friendly. Long time players are playing among actual newcommers and on top of that, they're using gear exploits - putting parts of their gun in the backpack, to fly below the maximum gear value limitation for example. And they use ammo, that a new player couldn't even afford. So.. maybe after around the first 5-10 matches, expect no mercy and a lot of grey screens.
-You'll often be thrown in matches 1v3/1v4, even if you chose that you wish to have teammates. And even if you'll have teammates, they'll often go their own way and will just use your death location, simply as information on where not to go.
-It's too hard to see opponents, yet they have no problem locating me. Also, too much vegetation and the bushes have eyes. It's so annoying to not experience fair gun fights as much as i'd like.
-The permanent confusion of: should i rush to get where i want to go as fast as i can, but make a lot of noise and possibly attract attention in the process or walk slow, but risk giving time for a potential sniper to glance in my direction.
-Thankfully rarely, but it can happen, that, you're clearly out of your opponents line of sight, behind a wall, but you still continue to take damage and die.
-Once you finish the quests and achieve the ultimate 3x3 secure case, the game kinda starts to lack meaning. You have to come up with some personal goals, like 100 million Koen balance for example or just continue playing for the sake of playing.
-This game will test your patience/personality. There are no loser protections in place. The opponents will not get worse to match your performance, because you're doing bad, all you can do is suck it up. You can get eliminated 20 times in a row and there's no system in place, stopping you from going into your 21st loss. You can go broke and not be able to afford to enter the higher game modes, for all they care. I guess it refers back to the word - Hardcore, that i mentioned before. (although the game sometimes throws thousands of Koen and gear for free your way, it can go dry, just as quickly)
-Looting boxes is mediocre in comparison to picking up opponents gear. Besides red items, which are rare and most often only in/near the few safes, looting is secondary and there's a huuge gap between them, in terms of potential expected value.
-There's only a handful of guns viable, if you want to stay competitive. Others are just there as filler. And most guns recoil-shake like crazy, even with expensive upgrades.

Positives:
+Great tutorial in which you can take your time and set your prefered controls on the go.
+There are some game modes, that can give a more forgiving experience, like Secure Ops. Although it only unlocks at level 18 and you still lose ammo/medication upon death and there's only one map at a time AND you will only get 30% of your loot value. Then there's Covert Ops, where you enter a Normal's lobby looking like a scav/bot, masquerading in front of regular players. You're given a random (trash) gun and gear, so you don't risk anything and you can play mindgames with the Normal players.
+There's a possibility to enter Normal's lobby completely for free (knife runs). It's a stress free (until you get some good loot) way to experience the game. Allows for zero-to-hero type of experience.
+There's no p2w aspects, the skins that people can buy don't have custom iron sights or anything. You also get some skins by simply playing the game, doing quests.
+The events are really cool and add to the gameplay experience. Like, find a computer and choose from a list of items, which ones you want sent to your storage or the pumpkin event, where you either purchased or got a couple pumpkins for free by playing the game and each time you extracted (up to 4 times), they doubled in value. As of writing this, there's a plane event - flying over Farm and dropping a huge box with valuable items, that the whole map is trying to contest.
+The maps are beautiful. The wind audio, the mountains in the background, the random rain, it's a vibe for sure.
+The depth of the game. Coming from mindless battle royales, i really liked, that i can be playing this game for 2 months and still figure out new things, experiment with settings, techniques etc.



That being said, would i recommend? As i usually say, in my reviews, give it a try, if you're interested. It's a free game after all and i can't say for certain, you'll love it or don't even bother. If you're a better-than-average FPS player with decent decision making, you can have a good time. But you have to like the 'big-highs, big-lows' aproach to gaming, to enjoy extraction shooters. As frustrating as it can be, i'll give it a thumbs up overall.

Arena Breakout is functionally my introduction to extraction shooters, and overall I'd say that it's done a pretty good job. I enjoy the gameplay loop of gearing up, looting, silencing the opps, and extracting with that sweet sweet Koen. However, this dignified cycle of systemic violence isn't exclusive to AB:I. So what sets this game apart for me?

Well, let's start with the goods. I truly adore the gun customization system. Nothing brings me more joy than purchasing a weapon bolt and building it into the firearm of my dreams, piece by piece. I also like the generally realistic visual style of all the weapons, armor, and other gear that one can acquire. I think that while the map selection is a bit limited at the moment, the ones that currently exist are solid and fun to play on. I don't know if there are direct analogs for it in other extraction shooters, but the Covert Ops game mode that spawns you in as an NPC militant with the worst gear in the world not only makes for profit margins that would inspire Mark Zuckerberg to buy another Hawaiian island but endows me with a deep appreciation for the brave men who nobly sacrifice their lives in going above and beyond the call of duty by shouting "give me your gun, I'll show you how to shoot!" before receiving the world's fastest open brain surgery at 750 rounds per minute. The healing system is actually great, and surprisingly satisfying to use. I was a bit turned off by it at first, but having 4 different functions for healing and the various levels of item that do each of the aforementioned functions make you feel like you're actually packing real medical supplies, and there truly is no feeling quite like realizing that no amount of bandages will perform surgery on my broken leg. The gunplay feels smooth, the inventory management is clean and intuitive, and- best of all- the game runs pretty well even on my laptop that already had sub-par VRAM when I bought it 3 years ago.

Now we unfortunately have to talk about the bads. Something that immediately comes to mind is that the game could do with a bit more mobility options. Not being able to mantle things that even me after hitting arms could overcome with ease, not being able to climb through windows, and the occasional finnicky-ness of going prone tend to take away from the overall experience. Another thing- I wish that the game would actually put good use to the rank points system and put you in games with people of similar rank, or at the very least similar net worth. To my dismay, I have found no evidence of any system resembling what I've just said. However, the one that really stands out to me is how the game handles armor, and the penetration thereof. Now, I know that the armor penetration system in this game is not new or innovative and that it's featured prominently in other games like Tarkov. However, the effectiveness of different ammo types and their importance therein feels so blown out of proportion to the point where it starts to break immersion. Yes, a 9mm HP should not blow the lung out of the body through any plate carriers. However, a 5.56 FMJ round should be at the very least a significant concern and at the most a death sentence to virtually anyone, no matter how expensive your face shield is. Despite this fairly non-inflammatory statement, people will tank 15 rounds of 5.56 FMJ to the chest like prime Houdini tanking punches, only to then proceed to slime me out with a single round of gold ammunition that costs as much as a 2011 Kia Sedona. Do players enjoy being able to have an innate advantage by spending what would normally be a good raid's profit for me on a dozen bullets? Obviously yes, otherwise no one would play this game. But to me, it's neither fun nor realistic to be able to exponentially increase your lethality by simply paying more, and for several reasons. For one- I don't like having to hit the TF2 Heavy monologue about how much money just went down the drain when I fired 6 rounds from an automatic rifle in CQC. Additionally, this system of making extremely expensive bullets further incentivizes camping and the use of sniper rifles, two tactics that are infamously un-fun to play against. Last of all, it makes an entire level of the ammo caste system- and mind you that being 75% of what you can actually loot from the world- borderline useless. If there's one good thing that comes from this, it would be the immense satisfaction I receive when I blick down a sweat with the entire contents of my 40 round magazine consisting entirely of grey ammo, then find that he had enough value in his glistening gold bullets alone to put a down payment on a house in the big 2025.

In conclusion, I enjoy this game quite a bit, enough to the point where I've been trying to convert my friends to playing it like I'm a missionary 2 days before the second coming of Christ. If you are one of those friends reading this- take this as a sign. Hop on. If you're not one of those friends, I nevertheless hope you enjoyed my review and the modestly funny jokes scattered throughout, and comment "skill issue" below to remind me that human interaction is temporary, but Koen is eternal.

On Armory, you get shot in a dark corner." My favorite is the ever-changing weather in the Dark Zone, which "alters every extraction into a new desperate gamble." So it's not just the sweaty guy with a sniper rifle you have to worry about, but also God himself, who apparently decided your loot run needed more atmospheric depression. Outthink, outgun, and extract before the zone and a sudden, scripted thunderstorm—swallows you whole.

2. "Effortless Mastery" and the 5% GPU Miner

The section "HYPER-REALISTIC, EFFORTLESS MASTERY" is a work of art. It's a love letter to military authenticity that also holds your hand and says, "There, there, just press this one button." It features the "Ultimate Gunsmith System" with over 900 mods. Because nothing says "effortless" like spending 45 minutes building a virtual rifle that will be lost to a 12 year old with a shotgun in the first 30 seconds of a raid.

But the real "effortless mastery" is the game's alleged side hustle of using 5% of your GPU. This isn't a bug; it's a feature! It's a subtle, immersive mini-game called "Cryptographic Extraction," where your PC quietly mines for a digital currency called "Koens" while you're busy looting them. Talk about a passive income stream!

3. My Tactical, Geometrically Distinct Squad

My personal raids are a testament to the game's diversity. I run with my two trusted operators:

BOX: My man whose nickname is a perfect, literal descriptor. With a head shaped like a Minecraft block and a beautifully bald, dark scalp, he provides an unparalleled tactical advantage. His cranium has 90-degree angles, creating natural ricochet opportunities. Enemies shoot at him and their bullets just fly off into the sunset, confused by the laws of physics. He's not just a soldier; he's a walking defensive structure.

Sukhoi: Our Turkish military consultant. This man doesn't just play the game; he lives it. When he gets shot in-game, he doesn't just flinch. He lets out a blood-curdling scream from his room, followed by frantic tactical jargon and the sound of him hitting the deck. We don't need surround sound; we just listen for Sukhoi's PTSD-induced battle cries to pinpoint enemy locations. It's the most immersive audio cue a squad could ask for.

4. The "We Promise We're Not Cheating" Anti-Cheat

The game's commitment to "Fair Play" is... aggressive. They proudly state they've issued 10-year bans to 123,000 players and reimbursed over 400 Billion Koens. Let that sink in. They had to create an entire in-game economy just to compensate for the sheer volume of cheaters. It's like a bank that's so good, it brags about how many times it's had to refund people after being robbed. "Automatic in-game compensation will hit your inventory." How comforting, to know that after being robbed by a teleporting aimbot, the system will automatically gift you a slightly used vest and a can of beans.

5. The Cyberpunk 2077 Crossover: Because Why Not?

Just when you thought the gritty, realistic military sim had an identity, it announces a crossover with Cyberpunk 2077. Because nothing screams "authentic tactical extraction" like a soldier in ghillie suit fighting a dude with neon pink cyber-arms and a talking shotgun. "Satisfy die-hard fans," it says. The "die-hard fans" of military realism must be thrilled to see Keanu Reeves offering them side-quests while they're trying to extract a broken LCD screen.

In conclusion, "Arena Breakout: Infinite" is a beautiful, chaotic paradox. It's a game that wants to be taken seriously while potentially turning your PC into a low-yield crypto farm. It's where my square-headed friend and my trauma-reenacting Turkish comrade can have the time of their lives, getting head-eyes'd by a hacker, only to be reimbursed with 400 billion units of a currency that probably has an inflation rate worse than Venezuela's.

I don’t even know where to start with Arena Breakout: Infinite. This isn’t a game — it’s a frustrating, soulless grind dressed up as a tactical shooter. Every second I spent in this mess felt like time being stolen from my life.

The gameplay? Clunky, inconsistent, and riddled with bugs that make every encounter feel like a gamble against broken mechanics instead of skill. Hit detection seems to operate on pure luck, and movement feels like wading through glue. Nothing about the gunplay feels satisfying — it’s all recoil, no reward.

The graphics try way too hard to look gritty and realistic, but the result is a washed-out smear of brown and gray. It’s as if the developers were allergic to color or joy. Sound design? Gunshots sound like someone snapping bubble wrap in another room.

And don’t even get me started on the monetization. Arena Breakout: Infinite is less a shooter and more a cash extraction machine disguised as a game. You can practically feel the developers reaching into your wallet every time you load into a match.

Matchmaking is a disaster, balance doesn’t exist, and the user interface looks like it was cobbled together at 3 a.m. by someone who’s never actually played a shooter. Performance issues, crashes, desyncs — it’s all there. This isn’t a “beta” problem. It’s a design philosophy problem.

In short: Arena Breakout: Infinite isn’t just bad — it’s aggressively unpleasant. It takes everything fun about tactical shooters, smothers it in paywalls and technical problems, and dares you to keep playing out of sheer masochism.

Avoid it like the plague. There are broken indie prototypes on Steam that offer more fun, balance, and respect for your time than this polished disaster.

    This is my first time touching the Extraction Shooter genre, so it’s hard to compare it with other games of the same type. I’ll just write the negatives and positives:

Negatives:
1)    UI/UX: In one word, “non-Newtonian fluid.” Let me explain:
1.1) UI: The game relies on an internet connection as if it’s a web browser game. Yes, it’s strange to say this about an online game, but let me explain. Literally any (except the game settings) ANY action in the game requests information from the server EVEN if you’re not in a match. Want to enter your inventory before the run — request to the server: “What does this loser have in their inventory?” Oh, changed your mind and decided to check the missions first — request: “What missions?” And because of that, if you press the inventory button several times in the main menu, the game will say “Don’t DDoS me, a**hole!”.
    Also, when you want to look at an item in-game, there’s a chance that its icon won’t load in time and you’ll have to wait a bit… And yes, I don’t have fast internet and I play with 60–80 ping, but is it really that hard to load compressed item icons during installation?
1.2) UX: In the game it’s unclear which objects you can jump onto and which you can’t, some rocks just have invisible walls or a few pixels you can stand on. 
     The door-opening animation is very slow… I’m not asking for slides or dives, but at least if you sprint into a door and it opened instantly, it would be much better…
1.3) Sprinting and jumping is a whole separate topic… And if you climb to the first step of a staircase, then the second, and then decide to drop from the second step to the ground — the noise will be as if you fell from one meter high. (Ladder is cursed too)
    Most likely it’s intentional, but sprint only works when moving forward (thanks for at least allowing diagonal sprinting).

2)   When launching almost any mode (I’ll write about modes below) solo, there’s a decent chance to get matched against a squad of 3 players, and a non-zero chance against a squad of 4.

3)   Purpose: The game itself doesn’t know what it wants to be. 
3.1) Rating gives almost nothing (ranked matchmaking can be turned off). 
3.2) Levels are just a wall between the player and the content, and the max level is 30. 
3.3) There are collection elements — but why? 
3.4) A bit of progression, but the important upgrades are only: crafting bullets that cannot be bought (level 3), and the speed of Hunger and Thirst change (level 3). 
3.5) There are supposedly 6 maps, but everyone plays on 2: the starting Farm or the last Arsenal (there are weirdos who love the TV Station because “you can be killed from any corner there,” I don’t see how that’s a plus). 
3.6) There are different modes, but “different” is a loud word: 3 of them differ from the classic only in the entry threshold of “gear cost” and loot prices on the map; one is 2 maps that rotate for some reason where you can extract without losing gear (but not consumables: bullets, meds, etc.); another is Solo mode (which is slightly broken by people who intentionally queue at the same time on one map to get into one match); another is playing as a bot (when there’s little time left in a match, a player is thrown into a bot’s body); and last is Gun Game from CS:GO. 
3.7) Missions: bring or kill. 
        Most likely this point exists simply because I don’t fully understand the genre, but there’s a strong feeling that if the devs focused at least on one aspect, the game would be more interesting.

4) Replays: You can only see a replay if you were killed, and hit info only if it was your kill or your death… No general match replays (sad, but not critical).

5) Spectating: Broken… If a squad has 3 players and you died, you can watch 2 operatives, but if one was killed while you were watching him and he was aiming, then when the second teammate aims, the spectator will see the dead player's POV aiming. (The same bug happens when switching between teammates while one of them is aiming). I won’t even talk about spectate delay — it’s not that big of a problem.

Neutral:
1) Sound:  In general the sound isn’t ideal, but I’ve heard worse. There is a bug where you run, stop, and the footstep sound flies forward. (Most likely thanks to the internet again, but there is no rubber-banding in those moments!).

2) Economy and Monetization: There’s no direct pay-to-win, but there is pay-to-lose-less… The safe storage you get either through a subscription or by completing all seasonal missions. A limit on how many items are waiting to be bought, a limit on how many items you can list per week. These limits can be overcome with donations (or increased a bit through progression)… If Monetization was only on skins (which are Pay-to-lose and I like it) and safe storage than this point would be a Positive, but the selling limit is ruining it...

Positives:
1) “Free at our home”: it’s a good chance to try the genre without spending money — though now I’m wondering whether all games in this genre are like this or not.

2) No rats: While playing, I almost never saw players ratting important places like “Extraction.” Yes, there are those who hide in rooms or bushes, but these players look more like cornered animals — the last survivors — rather than a coordinated ambush squad.

3) Good maps (those 2 that there are): They have both open areas for sniper gameplay and hidden paths where you can move unnoticed, which means good routes not only protect you from snipers in ambush but also help to flank snipers from behind. In turn, sniper groups can’t just lie and look in one direction — they have to move or control several angles (and don’t forget grenades).

4) Despite the fact that I criticized the game for internet dependency, there’s almost no rubber-banding (only when ping jumps to 600+). I was surprised that even with 300 ping I can still run wherever I want; the only problem is that the weapon doesn’t switch (but I understand that from the server’s perspective I’m in a different spot and can be killed even if I’m “already behind the wall”).
    I don’t know how the devs did it, but when playing with high ping, you can empty the whole mag, your game will correctly and instantly show where you hit, but the information about whether the enemy died arrives later. (And non-ironically, this is the best solution for high-ping players). At some point I even started moving my crosshair away earlier if I saw that I hit the needed spot several times, because I know enemy will be dead.



If they fix the overall flow of the game or make it less sluggish in player control or smoother on the server side, then I’ll gladly come back to it and burn my time in it. (I mean that I want the Interface and Player Control to feel sharper, while the Environment should be smoother, so it’s clearer where you can climb, how to get down quietly, and so you don’t have to “jump off staircase”…).
